Laws like #SB1 are going into effect in states across America.

1484194001720909829.text:
This law especially hurts seniors who rely on their children or grandchildren to drive them to the polling place.

If their child can't get time off to take them while the polls are open, they could miss the vote entirely.

1484194000265519111.text:
For parents who have to pick up their children from school, or workers who have to go their second job, or students who are going from work to class, regular polling hours are often just not enough.

And when polling places are closed and moved far away, it's even worse.

1484193998285811715.text:
Why should polling places be open 24 hours if employers have to let you take time off to go vote by law?

In TX, employers can refuse time off if you're not on the schedule for 2 hours while polls are open.

Because of polling place closures, voting lines can get up to 4-6hrs!

1484193996499042304.text:

But the work of the Civil Rights Movement, and the Voting Rights Act, does not stop there.

Now more than ever, we see the importance of protecting the vote. We are inspired by those who came before us and commit ourselves to carry on the fight against the #SuppressionSession

1421263986209734657.text:
On August 6, 1965, President Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act to protect the voices of millions of Americans.

This law created rules to expand voting rights and end Jim Crow suppression tactics against communities of color across the South.

1421263765136461828.text:
On Mar 7, 1965, John Lewis led a protest march across the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, AL, only to be met with brutal violence

Pushed to action by Bloody Sunday, demonstrations across America moved the country, and the federal government, to act.

1421263371702255619.text:
In 1955, the heroic actions of Rosa Parks led to the bus boycott in Montgomery, AL - the first big demonstration in the #CivilRightsMovement

From AL, the movement grew rapidly. Across the South, demonstrations drew thousands to protest segregation and #votersuppression

1421263285781999617.text:
It’s been 56 years since the #VotingRightsAct passed on August 6th, 1965.

1418635243033071617.text:
These #suppression tactics were on top of segregation laws, violence from the #KuKluxKlan, and other measures designed to make Black, Latino, and other communities in Texas second-class citizens.

Jim Crow laws effectively silenced minority voices in governments across the South.

1418635086296125447.text:
In 1902, Texas put in place a poll tax, which made voters pay a fee before they could go to their polling place to vote.

In 1923, Texas passed a White Primary law, which prevented non-white people from participating in the Democratic Party primary.

1418635024161705984.text:
After Reconstruction ended, states across the South began passing laws to suppress and eliminate the Black vote.

Southern states put in place laws like the Grandfather clause, poll taxes, white primaries, and more to prevent minority voters from exercising their rights

This history shows how important voter protections are, then and now.
We should make it easier to vote, not harder. We must protect #votingrights for all Americans.
Join me next week for the next part of the road to the Voting Rights Act

#VotingRightsFriday

1416152851278180353.text: The Federal government ended Reconstruction in 1876. This greatly hurt the future of voting rights for Black voters. Without Federal protection, voting restrictions and violence in the Jim Crow South caused the number of Black voters to plummet.

1416152815064526851.text:
These protections helped nearly 500,000 Black people vote in the 1870s. They also helped 2,000 Black public officials get elected.

Unfortunately, they would not last.

1416152773767352329.text: After the Civil War, Congress passed laws to enforce the 13th, 14th, and 15th amendment. These were some of the first laws in America to protect voting rights, and they worked.

1416152723674869769.text:
As we near 56 years since the #VotingRightsAct passed on August 6th, join me in looking at the history of the voting rights movement in America with Voting Rights Fridays!

Today is our first #VotingRightsFriday, looking at Reconstruction 🔽

1325156591188860928.text: 4/ Today, little girls and boys all across the country and, in fact, the world get to see the promise of America through her. As a woman, I could not be more proud of Madam Vice President-elect Kamala Harris.

1325156589687332868.text: 3/ Lastly, I must say something about the glass-ceiling shattering moment we are witnessing today. Kamala Harris just became the first woman, the first black person, and the first Southeast Asian person ever elected as Vice-President of the United States.

1325156588303290368.text: 2/ Together, they will heal a divided country as we work to control the spread of COVID-19 and help families affected by this virus build back better. The work ahead of us won’t be easy, but I know Joe and Kamala are ready to get to work.
